awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: ICARUS - Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a collaborative proposal to build an online, open-access, searchable, central repository for atmospheric chamber data in the United States called ICARUS (Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States).  Fundamental data obtained from chamber studies are routinely used as empirical inputs and constraints in atmospheric models. There are nine major U.S. research institutions participating in this project, including the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR).  This sustainable web-based infrastructure for storing, sharing, and using atmospheric chamber data will synergistically facilitate atmospheric chemistry research in the U.S.

The specific objectives of the project are to (1) provide a searchable public index of the chamber experiments from each participating research group; (2) archive past chamber data from each participating group under their indexed chamber experiment; (3) standardize chamber data reporting formats; (4) provide a uniform template for chamber metadata; and (5) streamline future data submissions.  The data products included in ICARUS are: (A) gas phase data that describes the time-resolved profiles of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as gaseous hydrocarbons, oxidized VOCs, oxidants (OH, O3, NO3), NOx, SO2, and other data; (B) particle phase data that describes yields of secondary organic aerosols (SOA) as well as optical properties, composition (detailed molecular and bulk elemental ratios), and chemical functional groups; (C) supporting information such as relative humidity, temperature, and light flux; (D) the experimental notes required to understand the data (such as reaction timing, mixing procedures, seed particle addition, and so on); and (E) vapor and particulate wall deposition rates that are needed to correct chamber data.  At the end of the 3-year project, the database will be transitioned to the Data Stewardship Engineering Team at NCAR.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
We (the UT Austin team) have completed our contributions to this ICARUS project; however, the PI’s team (Prof. Tran Nguyen, UC Davis) is continuing to finalize the product. I suggest referring to the final outcome report by Prof. Tran Nguyen (UC Davis) for the most final description of the project outcome.

 

Intellectual Merit: The overarching goal of the project was to create a sustainable web-based infrastructure for storing, sharing, and using atmospheric chamber data in the U.S, called ICARUS (Index of Chamber Atmospheric Research in the United States). The project development occurs in parallel with the development of the Data Asset Services Hub (DASH) at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR). The eventual plan is for the datasets and data management policies of ICARUS to integrate with DASH for long-term management at NCAR. We have completed that overarching goal. Specifically, our group has completed upload of past experiments, and we will continue to upload future experiments to the database after publication of the corresponding manuscripts.

 

Broader Impacts: We anticipate ICARUS to be a useful tool for education and undergraduate research. These data can be used to teach kinetics, modeling, curve fitting, atmospheric chemistry, or other topics – especially at schools/universities that do not have extensive physical infrastructure for research. The PI (Nguyen) plans to use these data in her environmental science classes as a hands-on module for students to learn about photochemistry and extraction of kinetic parameters; other professors may also freely use these data for education. During the pandemic, a large number of students cannot do on-site research; thus, working with a large variety of data to extract new information or evaluate models may be a productive exercise. It is possible that other uses will be discovered; the main objective of ICARUS is to promote the open access sharing and archival of publicly-funded data for any and all possible uses. This type of data availability promotes transparency, aligns with journal/grant data requirements, and works to support public trust in science.

 


Last Modified: 01/03/2022
Modified by: Lea Hildebrandt Ruiz
